instruction: How were partial least squares regression (PLSR) and back propagation-artificial neural network (BP-ANN) models used to predict the antioxidant capacities of rose petals during infrared drying (IRD) in order to improve drying efficiency and retain product quality?
Output: Partial least squares regression (PLSR) and back propagation-artificial neural network (BP-ANN) models were used in this study to establish the relationships between the near infrared (NIR) spectrum and the antioxidant capacities of rose petals during infrared drying (IRD). These models were used to predict the DPPH, ABTS radical scavenging capacities, and ferric-ion reducing antioxidant power (FRAP) values of the rose petals. The results showed that the BP-ANN model had higher prediction accuracy compared to the PLSR model for determining the antioxidant capacities. By using NIR spectral data and multivariate calibration, these mathematical models could reliably predict the antioxidant capacities of IR-dried rose petals, thus improving drying efficiency and retaining product quality.

Secondly, by establishing relationships between the NIR spectrum and the antioxidant capacities, mathematical models such as partial least squares regression (PLSR) and back propagation-artificial neural network (BP-ANN) can accurately predict the antioxidant capacities of the dried rose petals.
